title: Script Analysis: â€œElvisâ€â€Šâ€”â€ŠScene-By-Scene Breakdown
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Member-only story

Script Analysis: â€œElvisâ€ â€” Scene-By-Scene Breakdown

Here is my take on this exercise from a previous series of posts â€” How To Read A Screenplay:

After a first pass, itâ€™s time to crack open the script for a deeper analysis and you can do that by creating a scene-by-scene breakdown. It is precisely what it sounds like: A list of all the scenes in the script accompanied by a brief description of the events that transpire.

For purposes of this exercise, I have a slightly different take on scene. Here I am looking not just for individual scenes per se, but a scene or set of scenes that comprise one event or a continuous piece of action. Admittedly this is subjective and there is no right or wrong, the point is simply to break down the script into a series of parts which you then can use dig into the scriptâ€™s structure and themes.

The value of this exercise:

  • We pare down the story to its most constituent parts: Scenes.
  • By doing this, we consciously explore the structure of the narrative.
  • A scene-by-scene breakdown creates a foundation for even deeper analysis of the story.

title: How To Read A Screenplay
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Member-only story

How To Read A Screenplay

If youâ€™re serious about learning the craft, here are some ways to dig into scripts.

In this series, I have laid out one approach to reading and analyzing screenplays. This is not intended to train you to be a script reader, but rather to provide a set of tools for writers to dig deep into a screenplay and study its structure, characters, themes, style, and so forth.

As I say, every writer is different and has different needs, either personally or per project. If you resonate with any ideas here, feel free to use. If not, feel free to lose.

Reading scripts is a key part of immersing oneself in the world of cinema, something we all should be doing.

Remember: Itâ€™s more than just writing a screenplay. Itâ€™s about learning to think like a screenwriter.

title: Whatâ€™s Your Favorite Movie of the Year So Far?
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I love when you walk out of the theater after seeing a really good movie and everything just feels crisper. Then, you google everyone involved, get excited to chat with anyone whoâ€™s seen the movie in question, and find yourself still thinking about it weeks later. Hereâ€™s one movie from this year that did it for meâ€¦

Sorry, Baby bowled me over. Eva Victorâ€™s directorial debut, which they also wrote and starred in, follows Agnes through a few years of her life, sequenced out of order. Thereâ€™s â€œThe Year With The Babyâ€ and â€œThe Year With The Really Good Sandwich,â€ but also â€œThe Year With The Bad Thing.â€ When Eva shared the movie poster on Instagram, they confirmed that â€œnothing bad happens to the cat.â€

Instead, it is Agnes to whom the bad thing happens. â€œI wrote this film because thereâ€™s a part of my experience of trauma that I havenâ€™t seen on-screen often: the part where youâ€™re confused,â€ Eva said during a Sundance interview. â€œI spent years floating, just trying to accept that I went through something bad.â€ The movie â€œhonors those years lost,â€ as they put it. To write the script, Eva holed up in Maine one winter with their cat and many cans of split pea soup.

The warm friendship between Agnes and Lydie (Naomi Ackie) is the central love story animating the movie. But, as Lydieâ€™s life carries her away from the small town where they met during grad school, Agnes feels stuck. Getting an impressive teaching job at the university means staying in a place marred by a devastating experience during her time as a student. â€œBad thingâ€ is a euphemism, but also, with its childlike clarity, a perfect description.

Offering a really moving portrait of traumaâ€™s reverberations and one personâ€™s recovery, Sorry, Baby is also very funny.Â In the theater, I laughed a lot and cried a little. I loved Agnes and wouldâ€™ve been happy to spend a hundred years with her. Of the movieâ€™s reception, Eva recently told the L.A. Times,Â â€œI keep hearing, â€˜Oh, Agnes is so awkward.â€™ Iâ€™m like, â€˜What the hell?â€™ Iâ€™m very humbled by peopleâ€™s reactions to how bizarre they think that character is because Iâ€™m like: â€˜Oh, I thought she was acting legitimately normal, but okay.â€™â€

Whatâ€™s been your favorite movie so far this year? If you saw

Sorry, Baby, Iâ€™d love to know what you thought.

P.S. What are your top three movies of all time, and what movie can you watch over and over?

title: An Epic Week in NYC With Preteens
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
This past week, Antonâ€™s 13-year-old second cousin, Jimmy, came from England to visit Brooklyn. It was Jimmyâ€™s first time in the U.S., and we were all beyond excited. This morning, Anton and I were reminiscing, and we thought weâ€™d share photosâ€¦

Jimmy lives in a small seaside town in England, and Anton told me: â€œWe were joking around, like, â€˜Do you have cars in England? Do you have scooters in England? Do you have light in England? Do you have color in England?â€™ It was really funny. And sometimes when Jimmy would make a joke, we would be like, â€˜Is that funny in England?â€™ But his jokes were actually really funny.â€

Jimmy asked to see a few sights, and we were happy to oblige. â€œCan we go to the Louis Vuitton store that looks like suitcases?â€ he asked. I didnâ€™t even know this existed, but when we headed to 57th Street, there it was!

We took him to the American Museum of Natural History, one of our long-time favorite placesâ€¦

â€¦and to see Times Square at night, where Jimmy did a back flip for a crowd. â€œHe taught himself to do flips in his backyard when he was six,â€ Anton told me. â€œHe just fully went for it because he didnâ€™t know the consequences were that he could get his neck snapped!â€

The boys also begged me to take them to the Chelsea Piers driving range. They hit balls while I did the New Yorker crossword puzzle. â€œJimmy told me he wants to ride in a yellow school bus,â€ Anton told me. â€œHeâ€™s never done that.â€

We also just mucked around at homeâ€¦

â€¦and in the neighborhood. â€œWhen we were walking down the street, Jimmy was like, â€˜Look at that, look at that,â€™ because there were so many different kinds of foods â€” Japanese, Lebanese, Thai, Italian, Vietnamese, French, Chinese, Indian, Ethiopianâ€¦â€ said Anton. â€œHe also loved 16 Handles.â€

At the end of the week, Toby and my mom joined us, and we went to a neighborhood cafÃ© for coffee and magic tricks with cards. Jimmy showed us some cool ones, and I busted out my old favorite.

Finally, on Sunday, my brother and Jimmy headed back to England, and, honestly, we all felt really sad. Itâ€™s hard to live an ocean away from loved ones, as Iâ€™m sure many of you experience, as well. But weâ€™re so lucky to be able to keep in touch. When my maternal grandmother moved from Manchester, England, to Chicago with her new soldier husband, she could only exchange letters with her parents, until they visited many years later. Where do your relatives live? Are you close by? Half a world apart? How do you stay in touch? Iâ€™d love to hear. I know there are pros and cons to every arrangement. xoxo

P.S. Holy smokes, Iâ€™ve lived in NYC for 20+ years, and six NYC itineraries for kids.

title: A Letter to You
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
By the lovely Grace Farris.

P.S. Momsters and very minor holidays.

My heart! Tonight my kids piled into our bed to watch family videos from our favorites album on the iPad. I eventually put an end to it, even as they begged for more. I was stressed about bedtime, and tiredâ€¦oh so tired. Grace, you gave me a bit of perspective I needed tonight. Even in my stress and stupor, I know these are the days I will miss the most.

The perfect post to come upon, toddler asleep next to me, as I again question when it was that he was no longer a â€œbabyâ€â€”knowing that heâ€™ll always be my baby, even when he no longer sleeps beside me, even as we pass other families with baby babies at the grocery store while my baby walks by my side, even when he one day grows taller than meâ€”knowing this day will come sooner than my heart will be ready for, and Iâ€™ll reminisce in the grocery aisle, maybe tear up or put my hand over my aching mama heart, then Iâ€™ll buy the chips. Thank you, Grace, for the important and meaningful work you do, always.

Iâ€™m not much of a singer, but this makes me glad that I recorded myself reading The Gruffalo for my 4 year oldâ€™s Yoto player ğŸ¥¹

Love this. Definitely in the interminable bedtime universe and trying to savor it. My three year old calls out a lot and night and requests me to hold her hand. â¤ï¸ but yes, sometimes my sanity is called into question in this season with two littles.

Sitting here tearing up ( ok sobbing ) in the teriyaki place picking up an order for my daughterâ€™s birthday celebration while sheâ€™s at my house with my son in law waiting for me. 37 years ago at this time she was not even a day old yet. Sweet sweet memories. This post by Grace is beautiful. I DID cherish every second, and still do. It was just yesterday, wasnâ€™t it ?

Sob! Beautiful comment too

So excited to receive a text from 12yo almost 13, asking if I was going to shops and if I am can I get snacks so we can have snacks and watch a show. Any better Friday night invite?? No way. on the list maltesers, gum and chips. Hooray for chips.

so fun!!

My song for my oldest was â€œSweet Baby Jamesâ€ and when it comes on we just look at each other and have a sweet moment of connection.

More chips! So true. Anything salty.

Weâ€™re out of the lullaby phase (I Donâ€™t Want to Live on the Moon from Sesame Street was my go-to) but I did just rock out to Safe & Sound with my 2nd grader. Iâ€™ll be sure to cherish it all, even when heâ€™s asked Alexa to play it for the trillionth time.

I had a song list that I sang to all of my kids when they were small. They fell asleep or calmed down if I started singing the songs. Theyâ€™re all mostly grown now but they talk abt the songs sometimes. I miss singing to them and also reading to them. I read classic chapter books to them when they were in elementary school and had voices for all the characters. It was so fun. I miss it so much. Rocking them, reading to them, and singing to themâ€¦it went by so fast. Iâ€™ve had more years not doing those things with them now than doing them.

In the twinkling of your eye, they are 18, 21,35, 42, now my son is 53â€¦.

Man is this true. There is a card that is often on the rack right by the check out at the grocery store by me â€“ it says â€œI blinked and you grew upâ€. I literally start crying in the check out aisle every time. I would give anything for one more little boy bedtime snuggle â€“ mine are 24 and 26 now and well launched.

My heart!

This hits home.
We are dripping our daughter at college this weekend and moving her in.

title: A Week of Outfits: Sharon Beesley
excerpt: My friend Sharon Beesley broke my heart years ago when she moved from New York City to Guilford, Connecticut. But! She and her family thrived â€” she built a therapy practice and her kids moved from middle school to high school and, now, to college. Sharon and her husband Rob (wâ€¦
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
My friend Sharon Beesley broke my heart years ago when she moved from New York City to Guilford, Connecticut. But! She and her family thrived â€”Â she built a therapy practice and her kids moved from middle school to high school and, now, to college. Sharon and her husband Rob (who mom-and-dad-ed me through my divorce) are brand new empty nesters. Here, Sharon shares five outfits she wore in a week, including thrifted dresses, gardening overalls, and her favorite swimsuitâ€¦

Dress: thrifted. Hair clips: French combs. Shoes: Comfortiva.

â€œI thrift almost all my clothes, including this dress. My go-to store for anything special is Vintanthro in New Haven. They remember who I am, they know my kids. Theyâ€™ll be like, tell us about your upcoming event! Itâ€™s an old-school shopping experience, where they pull stuff and accessorize, and theyâ€™re just so excited for me.â€

â€œThen thereâ€™s Goodwill. You might come away with nothing, and you have to do it regularly. I go at least once a week with my kids. These days Iâ€™m into vintage sweatshirts and short-sleeve button downs, so Iâ€™ll just head to those sections because otherwise it can get overwhelming. It also depends on where you live â€” Iâ€™m lucky because I live in Connecticut and the Goodwills are super good here.â€

Tank: similar. Skirt: similar.

â€œThese days, for my hair, Iâ€™m doing the whole shower-then-keep-it-wet-and-donâ€™t-touch-it-and-put-in-Perfect-Hair-Day-by-Living-Proof-5-in-1-Styling-Treatment thing. It feels like a movement right now.â€

â€œBeing a therapist is SUCH a good job. Thereâ€™s something about listening to someoneâ€™s story for a full hour; I donâ€™t think we get to do that a lot in life. I try to understand exactly what each person is saying. If they say the word â€˜weirdâ€™ or â€˜you know what I mean,â€™ Iâ€™ll push to make sure Iâ€™m not making assumptions. I have to be careful with my kids because I donâ€™t want them to feel like theyâ€™re always in a therapy session. Sometimes Iâ€™ll ask, do you want me to offer therapy advice or do you want me to be a mom right now? If they want me to be a mom, Iâ€™ll just say â€˜thatâ€™s hardâ€™ and validate them.â€

Tee: thrifted. Overalls: thrifted, â€œhanded down from my son, itâ€™s the best having sons who are into thrifting,â€ similar. Sneakers: Converse.

â€œI have a bee tattoo. First, because my last name is â€˜Beesley,â€ and also because I went through a transition period, where I went from being Mormon to being not-Mormon and from being a stay-at-home mom to attending grad school for therapy. I had a lot of feelings about how Mormon women couldnâ€™t hold higher leadership roles, whereas bee hives are matriarchal. A few days before I started at Columbia, I had a few hours before I needed to pick up my kids from school. There are a million walk-in tattoo places in New York, so I picked one and got it. It was a thrill. The only problem with the tattoo is that itâ€™s on every pillow from T.J. Maxx to Michaels.â€

â€œAs a kid, I was obsessed with gymnastics, and then I didnâ€™t have an obsession for a long time, and now gardening has filled that space. My favorite things are watching gardening shows, reading gardening books, thinking about my garden, planting my garden, and watching my garden grow. My flowers cover the front yard, and I want to give our neighbors an experience â€” almost like an art installation, mimicking a field of wildflowers in the suburbs! It makes me happy to see people walk or drive more slowly as they pass by. I expect some flowers to get smashed or picked by toddlers â€” and I want them to. I should put out a sign that says, â€˜Please touch.'â€

Tank: Old Navy. Leggings: Old Navy. Sneakers: Nike. Dog: â€œPluto, the love of my life.â€

â€œI have a gap between my front teeth. Over the years, Iâ€™ve spent thousands of dollars trying to fix it â€” Invisalign, braces, porcelain veneers, temporary retainers, a permanent retainer â€” and finally, I was like, Iâ€™m not fighting this anymore. It only took me 40 years to embrace it, but now I love my gap.â€

title: Freddieâ€™s Baked Shrimp
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Freddie is one of those home cooks who can open a cupboard or fridge, stare at everything for a minute, and figure out a delicious meal to make with whatever he finds. Are you the same? It always impresses me, and I love to sit at the counter, do the New Yorker crossword puzzle, and watch him in action.

This summer, one of the meals he whipped up was spaghetti with tomato sauce, a green salad, and baked shrimp. A few readers asked about the shrimp, so I called Freddie this morning, and he told me the steps. Here goes:

Baked Shrimp by Freddie

â€œMy dad is a great cook, and one thing Iâ€™ve learned from him is how to make multiple courses at home and make it feel special. In our Italian-American family, macaroni is always part of the meal, always with a homemade sauce â€” thatâ€™s a point of pride. (Regardless of what kind of noodle it is â€” usually penne or ziti â€” we call it â€˜macaroni.â€™) For this specific dinner, I was trying to make something easy, so I could hang out with my parents and Joanna. Sliding a big tray of shrimp into the oven was a good way to do that.â€

Youâ€™ll need:
bag of frozen, pre-cooked shrimp
flour
salt
pepper
eggs
panko bread crumbs
spices, like paprika, garlic powder, onion powder (optional)
olive oil
lemon

Non-recipe recipe:

Preheat oven to 350F. Defrost the shrimp. Pull off the tails (if they still have tails) and pat dry.

Set out your standard three plates: flour (you can salt and pepper the flour, too, if youâ€™d like; Gordon Ramsay seasons almost every layer with salt and pepper; it seems like such a small thing but it really helps the final product), egg wash, and panko bread crumbs (seasoned, if youâ€™d like, with paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, salt, and pepper). Gently coat each shrimp in flour, then egg; then press the shrimp into the bread crumbs.

Put tin foil on a baking sheet and spread a thin layer of olive oil on top of the tin foil. Arrange the shrimp in a single layer on the foil. Then drizzle a little oil on top of the shrimp.

Bake in oven for 10-15 minutes. Before serving, drizzle lemon juice on top of shrimp.

Serve with pasta with tomato sauce and green salad, if youâ€™d like. You can eat the shrimp with the pasta or separately â€” breaded shrimp and red sauce can be so, so good. Enjoy!

Thoughts? What other shrimp recipes do you like? Here are a few CoJ favorites:

* shrimp with feta
* shrimp rolls
* chilled buttermilk-pea soup with shrimp
* five-ingredient Trader Joeâ€™s shrimp tacos
* shrimp salad platter
